Statistical evaluation of the agreement between predicted eigenvalues of the
shielding tensors and experimentally established eigenvalues of the
H chemical shift tensors of the
four proton sites in citric acid (12 data points).
The most challenging case for computational methods considered here is that of the The results
are less accurate for the cluster model, depicted in Figure
, with the RMSE of about 2.5 ppm
and the maximal error exceeding 5 ppm (see Table
). However, this cluster was created mainly
in order to check the orientation of the respective
H chemical shielding tensors in the molecular
frame (to avoid any possible confusion related to an orientation in the
acid in CASTEP calculations), as this spatial information should be useful in simulations of the 2D
]. It was, nevertheless, established that the results of the approach
used in the cluster calculations, GIAO-B3LYP
G(2d, 2p), should be of a quality similar to
G(2d, 2p), at least for hydrogen-bonded models (see Table SI10 showing the
H-NMR parameters in the phenol–water dimer). It was also veriﬁed that essentially
the same orientations in the crystal
molecular frame were provided by the GIPAW-PBE and the cluster
Hchemical shielding tensors in citric acid (Tables SI8 and SI9). These
orientations follow the pattern described for malonic acid in Part 2.1 and are shown in Figure
In particular, it should be realized that the angle is small between the O–H bond vector and the
, the eigenvector associated with the most shielded component,
be realized that the hydrogen bond direction can be roughly approximated by a vector between the
acceptor and donor oxygens. This vector is denoted here as
relates to one of the {H5, H6, H7, H8} protons of citric acid, and an angle
describes a mutual orientation of the hydrogen bonds involving H
